wikipedia_page.main: Agnes Cotton (27 February 1828 – 20 May 1899) was an English social reformer and philanthropist. She founded and ran a home in Leytonstone for fallen girls called The Pastures.

response: In 1812 he married Sarah Lane, a daughter of Thomas Lane of Leyton Grange. Their son William Charles Cotton was a clergyman and apiarist; Sarah Acland did good works; another son was the eminent jurist Henry Cotton and his sixth child, Agnes Cotton, was a philanthropist.Mary Clare Martin, ‘Cotton, Agnes (1828–1899)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008 accessed 17 March 2017
In 1895 Agnes Cotton opened a home for girls in Leytonstone. Cotton purchased what had been The Cedars. She renamed the house as The Pastures, and in time opened a larger home on the same site.
